slides.title: Welcome to Paleontology
slides.content:
# Introduction to Paleontology

Welcome to **Paleontology** - studying ancient life through fossils!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Fossils** - Types and formation
- **Geologic Time** - Earth's timeline
- **Mass Extinctions** - Major die-offs
- **Evolution of Life** - Through the ages

> **Fun Fact:** The dinosaurs lived from 230 to 66 million years ago!

slides.title: Fossils
slides.content:
# Fossils

## Definition:
Preserved remains or traces of ancient organisms.

## Types:

| Type | Description |
|------|------------|
| Body fossils | Actual remains |
| Trace fossils | Footprints, burrows |
| Molds | Impression in rock |
| Casts | Mineral fills mold |
| Amber | Preserved in resin |
| Frozen | Ice preservation |

## Formation Requirements:
- Rapid burial
- Hard parts (bones, shells)
- Right conditions (no oxygen)

## Index Fossils:
- Widespread, short time period
- Used to date rock layers
- Examples: Trilobites, ammonites

slides.title: Geologic Time Scale
slides.content:
# Geologic Time Scale

## Major Divisions:

| Era | Period | Major Events |
|-----|--------|-------------|
| Cenozoic | Quaternary, Neogene, Paleogene | Mammals, humans |
| Mesozoic | Cretaceous, Jurassic, Triassic | Dinosaurs |
| Paleozoic | Permian to Cambrian | Fish, amphibians, plants |
| Precambrian | Proterozoic, Archean, Hadean | First life |

## Key Dates:

| Event | Time Ago |
|-------|----------|
| Earth forms | 4.5 bya |
| First life | 3.8 bya |
| Cambrian explosion | 541 mya |
| First land plants | 470 mya |
| First dinosaurs | 230 mya |
| K-T extinction | 66 mya |
| First humans | 300,000 ya |

bya = billion years ago
mya = million years ago

slides.title: Dating Methods
slides.content:
# Dating Fossils

## Relative Dating:
- Order of events, not specific ages
- **Superposition:** Older layers below
- **Cross-cutting:** Intrusions younger than what they cut
- **Index fossils:** Known time ranges

## Absolute Dating:
- Specific numerical ages
- Radiometric dating

## Radioactive Decay:

| Isotope | Half-Life | Use |
|---------|-----------|-----|
| Carbon-14 | 5,730 years | Recent (<50,000 years) |
| Potassium-40 | 1.3 billion years | Old rocks |
| Uranium-238 | 4.5 billion years | Ancient rocks |

## Half-Life:
Time for half the parent isotope to decay.

```
After 1 half-life: 50% remains
After 2 half-lives: 25% remains
After 3 half-lives: 12.5% remains
```

slides.title: Mass Extinctions
slides.content:
# Mass Extinctions

## The Big Five:

| Extinction | Time | Cause | Lost |
|------------|------|-------|------|
| Ordovician | 444 mya | Glaciation | 86% |
| Devonian | 375 mya | Unknown | 75% |
| Permian | 252 mya | Volcanism | 96% |
| Triassic | 201 mya | Volcanism | 80% |
| Cretaceous | 66 mya | Asteroid | 76% |

## K-T Extinction:
- Asteroid impact (Chicxulub crater)
- Killed dinosaurs (non-avian)
- Allowed mammals to diversify

## Permian Extinction:
- Largest mass extinction
- Siberian Traps volcanism
- Nearly ended complex life

## Recovery:
- Takes millions of years
- New groups fill niches
- Leads to evolutionary radiation

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Paleontology Summary

## Fossils:
- Body fossils, trace fossils
- Require rapid burial
- Index fossils date rocks

## Geologic Time:
| Era | Key Life |
|-----|----------|
| Cenozoic | Mammals, humans |
| Mesozoic | Dinosaurs |
| Paleozoic | Fish, amphibians |
| Precambrian | First life |

## Dating:
- Relative: Order (superposition)
- Absolute: Radiometric (half-lives)

## Mass Extinctions:
- 5 major events
- Permian: 96% lost
- K-T: Dinosaurs extinct

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Paleontology!
